trans-unit.source: The exception that is thrown when a <xref href="System.Threading.Thread"></xref> is in an invalid <xref href="System.Threading.Thread.ThreadState"></xref> for the method call.
Once a thread is created, it is in at least one of the <xref:System.Threading.ThreadState> states until it terminates.
`ThreadStateException` is thrown by methods that cannot perform the requested operation due to the current state of a thread.
For example, trying to restart an aborted thread by calling <xref:System.Threading.Thread.Start%2A> on a thread that has terminated throws a <xref:System.Threading.ThreadStateException>.
<xref:System.Threading.ThreadStateException> uses the HRESULT COR_E_THREADSTATE, which has the value 0x80131520.
For a list of initial property values for an instance of <xref:System.Threading.ThreadStateException>, see the <xref:System.Threading.ThreadStateException.%23ctor%2A> constructors.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Threading.ThreadStateException"></xref> class with default properties.

This constructor initializes the `Message` property of the new instance to a system-supplied message that describes the error, such as "The requested operation cannot be performed on the thread due to its current state."
This message takes into account the current system culture.
The following table shows the initial property values for an instance of <xref:System.Threading.ThreadStateException>.
Property
Value
`null`.
The localized error message string.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Threading.ThreadStateException"></xref> class with a specified error message.
This constructor initializes the `Message` property of the new instance using the `message` parameter.
The following table shows the initial property values for an instance of <xref:System.Threading.ThreadStateException>.
Property
Value
`null`.
The error message string.
The error message that explains the reason for the exception.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Threading.ThreadStateException"></xref> class with serialized data.
This constructor is called during deserialization to reconstitute the exception object transmitted over a stream.
For more information, see [XML and SOAP Serialization](~/docs/framework/serialization/xml-and-soap-serialization.md).
The <xref href="System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationInfo"></xref> that holds the serialized object data about the exception being thrown.
The <xref href="System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext"></xref> that contains contextual information about the source or destination.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Threading.ThreadStateException"></xref> class with a specified error message and a reference to the inner exception that is the cause of this exception.
An exception that is thrown as a direct result of a previous exception should include a reference to the previous exception in the <xref:System.Exception.InnerException%2A> property.

The <xref:System.Exception.InnerException%2A> property returns the same value that is passed into the constructor, or `null` if the <xref:System.Exception.InnerException%2A> property does not supply the inner exception value to the constructor.
The following table shows the initial property values for an instance of <xref:System.Threading.ThreadStateException>.
Property
Value
The inner exception reference.
The error message string.
The error message that explains the reason for the exception.
The exception that is the cause of the current exception.
If the innerException parameter is not `null`, the current exception is raised in a `catch` block that handles the inner exception.
